description.narrative: The overall goal is to increase the income levels of poor rural households involved in the production, value adding and trade of agricultural commodities. The programme aims to achieve this by increasing the volume and value of agribusiness based on the output of small-scale producers.SAPP will support the realignment of functions between the public and private sectors, completing the transition process that started in the 1990s. In essence, GRZ will deliver public-good type services to agribusiness including, research and extension, the application of quality, health and safety regulations, development project management, and maintenance of an enabling commercial environment built around the common law of contract. Interventionist activities such subsidised input and marketing operations, are being transferred to the private sector, outsourced or downsized.The Programme's institutional strategy is to work through, complement and strengthen the main actors at the various levels in selected value chains, including government agencies, cooperatives, NGOs, agribusiness enterprises, farmer organisations, and other programmes and projects. In this way, the expected institutional outcomes of the Programme are:a) MACO, through the SAPPO and its contracted service providers, coordinating Programme initiatives and taking the lead in policy development in the areas of private sector partnership-building and value chain enhancement;b) MACO's ABM Department with the capacity to take full responsibility for the formulation and execution of key policy and regulatory functions and the creation of an enabling environment for rural commercial development which is inclusive of small-farmers;c) private sector partners willing to enter into mutually beneficial PPPs which deliver the desired outcomes in terms of agricultural commercialisation and rural poverty reduction, as well as profitable and sustainable agribusiness enterprises;d)Provinces and Districts with improved capacity to support agribusiness development which meet the specific needs small-scale farmers and other actors in the selected value chains;e)sustainable and self-financing farmer organisations, enterprise groups, trade associations, and commodity task forces providing support services fully engaged in the implementation of Programme activities, and policy/regulatory reform; andf)productive and mutually beneficial partnerships with a range of sub-sectoral institutions, service providers and industry organisations.
This point represents the centroid of the project area. For more detailed geographic information, please refer to the project page on the IFAD website.
